results.headline: Look but Don’t Touch: It’s All About the Hair
results.summary_short: Spirited, probing and frequently hilarious, “Good Hair” coasts on the fearless charm of its front man and the eye-opening candor of its interviewees.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Good Hair

results.headline: Small-Town Striving
results.summary_short: “Free Style” is about motocross and stars Corbin Bleu of the Disney Channel repertory company, two facts that might lead you to expect a certain kind of film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Free Style

results.headline: Beware of Strangers Bearing Champagne
results.summary_short: If in hindsight “An Education” might make you a little queasy, it is hard to resist.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of An Education

results.headline: Still Hungry
results.summary_short: In “Eating Out 3,” the sex (of which there isn’t much) isn’t sexy, and the humor isn’t funny.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eating Out-All You Can Eat

results.headline: Bickering in Paradise: Honeymoon Is Definitely Over
results.summary_short: “Couples Retreat” is a comedy of exhaustion. But it is the comedy itself, in both concept and execution, that seems tired.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Couples Retreat

results.headline: Portrait of the Criminal as a Performance Artist
results.summary_short: Nicolas Winding Refn’s “Bronson” is a highly stylized and embellished film biography of a man known as the most famous prisoner in Britain.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bronson

results.headline: Surrounded by Outrages and Taking Inventory
results.summary_short: in “Stark Raving Black,” Lewis Black’s concert movie, the comedian is at his most eloquently splenetic.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stark Raving Black

results.headline: Visual Poetry: The Rhythms of Venezuela’s Salt Workers
results.summary_short: “Araya” comes preapproved, but not everyone will be convinced.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Araya

results.headline: A Troubled-Waters Musical as a Community Salve
results.summary_short: “After the Storm” follows a troupe of youngsters in New Orleans as they stage a benefit performance of the musical “Once on This Island.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of After the Storm

results.headline: Calls to God: Always a Busy Signal
results.summary_short: “A Serious Man” is, like its biblical source, a distilled, hyperbolic account of the human condition.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Serious Man

results.headline: Camera Lingers Near Another Lost Boy
results.summary_short: Audiences will leave “Afterschool” unnerved, which is probably exactly what its director had in mind.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Afterschool

results.headline: Art From the Holocaust, Behind the Barbed Wire
results.summary_short: “As Seen Through These Eyes” feels like a glib, streamlined examination of a painful, complicated subject.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of As Seen Through These Eyes

results.headline: Restless Natives in Algeria
results.summary_short: “Intimate Enemies” is a movie you’ve seen before, when it was set on the Apache reservation or in the Vietnamese jungle.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of L' ennemi Intime

results.headline: Following a Gore-Slicked Path
results.summary_short: “Zombieland” is a minor diversion dripping in splatter and groaning with self-amusement.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zombieland

results.headline: Misfits With Big Hearts and Roller-Derby Grit
results.summary_short: “Whip It” is predictable not only in the contours of its plot, but also in nearly every scene and situation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Whip It

results.headline: Akron’s Little Dribblers Who Became Big Shots
results.summary_short: “More Than a Game” looks back on the achievements of a high school basketball team in Akron, Ohio, that happened to include LeBron James.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of More Than a Game

results.headline: Bollywood Laughs
results.summary_short: Vulgar, noisy and excessive, “Do Knot Disturb” is a Bollywood sex farce with almost no sex.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Do Knot Disturb

results.headline: A World Where Truth Turns Out Not to Be Beauty
results.summary_short: “The Invention of Lying” is a mostly funny if melancholic defense of deceit.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Invention of Lying

results.headline: A Grand Central Station of High Times
results.summary_short: “Chelsea on the Rocks” is madly infatuated with the Hotel Chelsea’s notoriety as a nexus of sex, drugs and rock ’n’ roll.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chelsea on the Rocks

results.headline: Mean Streets and Meaner People
results.summary_short: Nerve may be the one thing “A Beautiful Life” does not lack.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Beautiful Life
